column2: Any single character except a newline (by default). Use re.DOTALL flag to include newlines.

column1: What is the difference between * and + quantifiers?
column2:
*: match 0 or more of the preceding element.
+: match 1 or more. So a* matches empty string; a+ requires at least one 'a'.
Makes the preceding element optional (0 or 1 occurrence). Also used to make quantifiers lazy when placed after *, +, or {n,m}.

column1: What is the difference between greedy and lazy matching?
column2:
Greedy (default): quantifiers match as much as possible.
Lazy: add ? after a quantifier (e.g., *?) to match as little as possible.

^: matches the start of the string (or line in multiline mode).
$: matches the end of the string (or line in multiline mode).
Matches any single character listed inside the brackets. [aeiou] matches any vowel. [a-z] matches any lowercase letter. [^abc] matches any character NOT in the set.

column1: What are common shorthand character classes?
column2:
\d: digit [0-9]
\w: word character [a-zA-Z0-9_]
\s: whitespace [ \t\n\r\f\v]
\D, \W, \S: their negations.
Parentheses group part of a pattern and capture the matched text. The captured value can be referenced via group(n) or in a replacement string as \1.
Groups a pattern without capturing the matched text. Useful for applying quantifiers to a group when you don't need to reference the match later.

(?=pattern): positive lookahead — matches a position followed by pattern, without consuming it.
(?!pattern): negative lookahead — matches if NOT followed by pattern.

(?<=pattern): positive lookbehind — matches a position preceded by pattern.
(?
Alternation — matches either the expression on the left or the right. (cat|dog) matches "cat" or "dog".
A word boundary — matches the position between a word character (\w) and a non-word character. Useful to match whole words: \bword\b.
Matches between n and m repetitions of the preceding element. {3} exactly 3, {3,} at least 3, {3,6} between 3 and 6.
\1 (or \2, etc.) refers to the text captured by the nth capturing group earlier in the pattern. Example: (\w+) \1 matches repeated words like "hello hello".
Pre-compiles a regex pattern into a reusable object. More efficient when using the same pattern multiple times, as it avoids recompiling on each use.

column1: What is the difference between re.match and re.search?
column2:
re.match: only checks for a match at the beginning of the string.
re.search: scans the entire string for the first location where the pattern matches.
A list of all non-overlapping matches of the pattern in the string. If there are capturing groups, returns a list of tuples of the captured groups.
Replaces all matches of a pattern in a string with a replacement string or function. re.sub(r'\d+', 'NUM', 'abc 123') → 'abc NUM'.

re.IGNORECASE (re.I): case-insensitive.
re.MULTILINE (re.M): ^ and $ match line boundaries.
re.DOTALL (re.S): . matches newline.
re.VERBOSE (re.X): allow whitespace and comments in pattern.
